text_elements.text: Optimizing Query ClassificationIterative Prompt Refinement and Performance Analysis

Context
LLM performance linked to instruction clarity and quality

Classification Task
Retrieval | Step-by-step reasoning | Direct answer

Evaluation Metrics
Routing Accuracy	Answer Accuracy
Efficiency

Approach
Six versions: simple prompt → structured framework
Early Iterations (V1-V3)

V1: Simple Baseline
Approach: Minimal instruction, binary classification
Results: 52.3% routing accuracy, 16.59% retrieval identification
Issue: Strong anti-retrieval bias, insufficient for smaller models

V2: Aggressive Safety-First
Approach: Strong bias toward retrieval as default
Results: 66.7% routing accuracy, 98.22% retrieval, 26.07% general knowledge
Issue: Over-correction led to inefficient, redundant processing

V3: Balanced Criteria
Approach: Explicit categories with two-step reasoning
Results: ~98% retrieval accuracy, but general knowledge dropped to 21.27%
Issue: Sequential checklist approach remained problematic
Advanced Iterations (V4-V6)

V4: Profile-Based Classification ⭐
Approach: Holistic classification matching queries to detailed profiles Results: 82.0% routing accuracy, 91.88% retrieval, 69.36% general knowledge
Impact: 95.27% answer accuracy (20.35pp better than baseline)
Breakthrough: Leveraged LLM's pattern-matching, introduced 'Recent Events'

V5: Guiding Principle
Approach: Added tie-breaker: "slow but correct > fast but wrong"
Results: 81.1% routing accuracy, 92.0% retrieval, 67.07% general knowledge
Philosophy: Accuracy-first principle with safety default

V6: Efficiency-Focused ⚡
Approach: Non-retrieval as default unless clear trigger present Results: 72.6% routing accuracy, 58.77% retrieval, 90.47% general knowledge
Achievement: 97.18% answer accuracy for general knowledge (22.26pp over baseline)
Trade-off: Sacrificed complex query accuracy for efficiency gains

Key Insights
Instruction engineering provides high degree of control over LLM behavior
Simple prompts insufficient for reliable routing in smaller models
Profile-based classification outperforms sequential checklists
Clear trade-off between accuracy and efficiency
V5 optimal for reliability (accuracy-first systems)
V6 optimal for efficiency (speed-critical systems)

Conclusion
Instruction choice depends entirely on desired system behavior and priorities
Research Alignment: Prioritizing efficiency when trade-offs prove worthwhile
Adaptive Query-Routing Framework for Optimizing Small Language Models
